abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Economic Recovery
            Development Policy Operation (DPO) Project for Malawi were
            as follows: outcomes were unsatisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was high, Bank performance was
            moderately unsatisfactory, and Borrower performance was
            moderately unsatisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            the breakdown of Malawi’s public financial management (PFM)
            that occurred in 2013 highlights the need for a thorough
            understanding of the local political economy of reform and
            the importance of looking beyond the veneer of formal
            rules-based systems, to the underlying informal arrangements
            that allowed for collusive behavior to take place.
            Development policy financing can be seen as a two-edged
            sword with the provision and then suspension of budget
            support serving to amplify political and business cycles in
            the economy. The Bank and other common approach to budget
            support (CABS) donors are not currently disbursing DPOs3
            policy dialogue on the issues continues and by keeping the
            option of resuming budget support at a future date on the
            table, there are positive incentives in support of critical
            reforms. The most notable area of progress was on reforms to
            fertilizer procurement under farm input subsidy program
            (FISP), an area that lays at the core of Malawi’s public
            policy, where the introduction of a revised tonnage
            allocation formula helped reduce costs and improve
            allocative efficiency. DPOs can play an instrumental role
            and as part of a mix of aid instruments by helping (at the
            margin) to support critical reforms necessary for stronger
            and more resilient growth and poverty reduction.
